question: How will higher miles per gallon in cars affect how long the world’s oil supply lasts?

content.source_1: Gasoline is refined from crude oil; when less gasoline is burned, less crude oil must be extracted and processed, so a finite oil stock lasts longer, other things equal.
content.source_2: For a given amount of driving, an increase in miles per gallon reduces the amount of gasoline consumed.
content.source_3: Improving fuel efficiency lowers the fuel cost per mile, which induces people to drive more (the rebound effect), especially over the long run.
content.source_4: If the induced increase in total miles driven is proportionally larger than the improvement in miles per gallon, then total gasoline consumption increases despite the efficiency gain.
content.source_5: In rapidly motorizing economies that account for much of the growth in global vehicle travel, reductions in operating costs have been observed to trigger large—sometimes more-than-proportional—long-run increases in vehicle travel and fuel use.
content.source_6: If total global gasoline consumption rises, the finite world oil supply is drawn down faster, shortening the length of time it remains available.

answer: extending the time that oil will be available for people to use.
